description.narrative: Support the generation and use of robust evidence by national and regional stakeholders working to improve Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights across East and Southern Africa.

HEARD, ett multidisciplinärt forsknings- och utbildningsinstitut vid University of KwaZulu-Natal, Sydafrika, har ansökt om finansiering från det regionala SRHR-teamet vid Ambassaden i Lusaka. Förslaget från HEARD omfattar ett fyraårigt program 2018-2021 till en kostnad motsvarande cirka 78 miljoner kronor.
Programmet syftar till att främja och stödja SRHR arbetet i södra och östra Afrika genom att generera ny kunskap och att stödja användningen av kunskap i beslutsfattande inom hälsa och SRHR-området. HEARD syftar till att (i) minska avståndet mellan forskning och beslutsfattare, (ii) genomföra riktad, tillämpad, forskning för att göra politiska och finansiella investeringar inom SRHR mer effektiva. (iii) skapa en regional plattform för evidensbaserat beslutsfattande inom SRHR och hälsa.
HEARD kommer inom ramen för interventionen att bedriva tillämpad forskning, genomföra forskningsutbildningar och utbildningar för beslutsfattare och slutligen bedriva påverkansarbete gentemot beslutsfattare.
Ambassaden har samarbetat med HEARD sedan drygt tio år tillbaka och under den senaste insatsperioden (2011-2017) har Ambassaden gett HEARD kärnstöd. Det är ambassadens bedömning att HEARD under kommande projektperiod måste minska sitt beroende av kärnfinansiering från Sverige och skapa en långsiktigt hållbar grund för finansiering.

Then intervention comprises support to HEARD at the University of KwaZulu-Natal, SA, for advancing SRHR priorities across the Eastern and Southern Africa (ESA) region. The overarching goal of the intervention is to ensure that the uptake of robust, comprehensive evidence drives improvement in SRHR across ESA.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.

title.narrative: HEARD - Realisation of SRHR for all - 2018-2021
HEARD - Realisation of SRHR for all - 2018-2021

description.narrative:
To achieve its objectives HEARD targets; researchers, decision makers in key policy positions at national and regional level and community level advocates across the East and Southern African region. HEARD employs three key strategies to engage its target groups to generate evidence and disseminate evidence through; establishing research clusters, funding PhD studentships, curating technical workshops or technical knowledge consulting where requested, and hosting and moderating high level meetings in the region to advocate for evidence informed reforms.
The below results are examples reported from HEARDS's Annual Report 2020 .
• HEARD established the joint Ministers of Health and Ministers of Finance virtual task group to understand the heath and economic impacts of Covid-19. The aim is to assist African governments with impartial and peer focused discussion on the evolving challenges posed by the pandemic and the impacts and affects this has on health. 30 members were drawn from 22 countries. • Co-chairing and preparing background documents to the UN-Universal Health Coverage committee for promotion of access to services for marginalised groups. • Support to SADC in the development of Minimum Standards for protection of SRHR key populations, providing the evidence base for the SADC PF to adopt key policy and legal directives from a parliamentary perspective for the protection of key populations. • HEARD advises policy an practice regarding the access to SRH of young people in detention in Madagascar. SRHR-services • HEARDs research clusters and students work to understand the social economic drivers and extent of unsafe abortion in East and Southern Africa. Examples of outputs of the cluster include the initiation of research to undercover the challenges of adolescent and young female sex workers in Zimbabwe, other outputs include an analysis of the provision of post abortion care services for women and girls in Eastern and Southern Africa. • HEARD facilitated the development of emergency request from Uganda to the Global Fund for support to PLHIV, people with TB and members of key populations harshly affected by the Covid-19 pandemic. • HEARD led the process to secure USD 122 million from the Global Fund to fund programmes related to HIV, TB and Malaria as well as critical health systems in South Sudan.
• HEARD continues to use its expertise, networks and depth of knowledge to push boundaries through the PhD programme with a number of published pieces, with 26 publications and 2 books produced in 2020 alone. • HEARD participated in the development of a implementation guide for programmes addressing and removing human rights and gender-related barriers to HIV-services. The guide was launched in April 2020 and was developed in collaboration with Frontline AIDS and the Global Fund. • HEARD confidentially provided direct support to five African governments in their efforts to repeal restrictive laws on abortion. • To promote the use of evidence two workshops were held in partnership with ARASA on safe abortion and UHC.
HEARD works in collaboration with other partners to provide evidence or capacity that can be used to hold member states accountable. ARASA is one such three year collaboration to advance SRHR in the region by building capacity in civil society. In 2020, the collaboration successfully supported five week courses on access to abortion and UHC and SRHR respectively where HEARD provided inputs into content development, analysis, work shop delivery as well as accreditation of trainings. In this way HEARD scales the use of evidence in SRHR advocacy strategies in the region.
